introScreens.title: What is CarbonXP?
introScreens.description: Carbon XP is an educational tool created to bring awareness to the interconnectedness between human activity and our environment.
Use this platform to learn about a few of the ways your daily activities create greenhouse gas emissions, and to hear directly from people all over the planet about climate change.

homeScreen.title: Activities
info: Carbon Experience
These activities were carefully designed to allow you to dictate your personal climate change learning experience. Choose an activity to find out more.
If you have an idea for an activity you think should be included in CarbonXP, see the credit page, accessed from the home page of this app, for contact information!

intro.title: Carbon Counter
intro.description: This activity will provide information about the greenhouse gas emissions that are produced as a result of some of your daily activities. The results will help you better understand your carbon footprint.
intro.disclaimer: Note: this activity captures just a few activities and is not a total picture of your carbon footprint, it is just an estimate of one slice of your life
info: Greenhouse Effect

It has been well understood for nearly two centuries that certain gases in the atmosphere trap heat that is coming off the earth's surface that would otherwise be quickly lost to space. This is called the "greenhouse effect" and those gases are called "greenhouse gases" or "GHGs".

Our planet gets significant warmth from the impact these gases have in our atmosphere and, without them, earth would be too cold for liquid water or to support life as we know it. But, the gases do their job so well, that as human activities add more and more of them to the atmosphere, the earth's average temperature has and will continue to increase.
Why Carbon?
Many of our regular activities rely on the burning of fossil fuels or other processes that release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.

Carbon dioxide is the greenhouse gas of biggest concern because it is released when we burn fossil fuels (which is the world's primary source of energy, so we release a lot of it) and because it is extremely long lived in the atmosphere.

However, there are other powerful greenhouse gases, such as methane (produced in nature and by human activity) and fluorinated gases (produced only by humans for industrial use and have no natural source).
Take the Carbon Counter Survey and see the results page for more information about how greenhouse gas emissions are measured.

household.title: Household
questions: How many other people do you live with?
info: Zip Code
Your zip code allows us to determine the type of fuels that are likely used to power your home (e.g., heat, cool, and provide electricity) where you live.
House size

The size of your house primarily determines how much energy is used to heat or cool your home and how much electricity is used to power things like appliances. However, there are other factors such as how old or energy efficient your home is that can make a difference in the amount of energy used. This exercise will give you a general estimate based on average homes in your area and does not take into account specific circumstances that might make your home use more or less fossil fuels
Who you live with

If you live with others in the home, then all the energy used in your home is not just for you, others get the benefit from that same amount of energy used. The number of people in your household is used to calculate the emissions that should be attributable just to you.

transportation.title: Transportation
questions: Approximately how many miles do you travel (round trip) to school on an average day?
What is closest to your primary mode of transportation?
How does your summer travel compare to your school year travel?
info: Transportation

In this section, we assume that your primary use of transportation modes is to get to school and back. Then, we factored in a multiplier of that number based on your response regarding summer travel patterns.

diet.title: Diet
questions: How many servings of beef do you have in a typical week?
How many servings of dairy (cheese, milk products, eggs) do you have in a typical week?
info: What is a serving?

For the number of servings, it is fine to just guess — the idea is simply to give yourself an idea of the emissions impact of various food choices. But, if you want to try to be more precise, a "serving" is described below:
Beef
1 serving = 4 ounces, about the size of a deck of cards
Dairy
1 serving of eggs = 2 eggs
1 serving of milk products (milk, yogurt, etc) = 8 ounces, about the size of a baseball
1 serving of cheese = 3 ounces, about the size of 12 dice or three individual string cheese
Diet Calculations

We deliberately picked two relatively high impact food choices. We omitted pork but its emissions profile is less than beef but more than dairy. Producing plant based foods generally emits fewer greenhouse gas emissions. Animal based food requires feed (that must be grown and processed), land, and more water than plant based food.

Cows are especially greenhouse gas intensive because they are ruminant animals. They have a special digestive system that produces methane (cow burps). Cows are just one part of the greenhouse gas emissions produced in the agricultural system, and agriculture is just one part of the greenhouse gas emissions produced by human activity.
Many people are also working on novel solutions that would not depend on changing dietary preferences around the world.

shopping.title: Shopping
questions: In the last 3 months, how many articles of new clothes have you purchased?
info: Shopping

The amount of greenhouse gases emitted to produce different types of clothing (e.g., pants, dresses, socks, etc) will vary based on the materials, method, and energy sources used. We use data from the production of an "average" t-shirt for this question to give you an idea of your clothing shopping impacts.

Of course, there are many things we buy and use that are not captured by this question, such as electronics, cosmetics, toiletries, games, appliances, food, and much more. But this is meant to give you a snapshot of one aspect of your life. Next time you touch any object, imagine how and where it might have been made, and the energy source and materials that were needed to make and transport it.

There are many people in the world working hard to change the way we make and transport things, what happens to things at the end of their useful lives, and where we get the energy to make the things we enjoy. We do not have to go without the things we like or that make life easier in order to address climate change.
CO2 Equivalents

In order to account for the variety of different gases that all have warming potential, greenhouse gas emissions are often expressed as "carbon dioxide equivalents" (abbreviated as CO2-e), which is a unit of measure used to include all greenhouse gases based on their warming potential as compared to the same amount of carbon dioxide.

The "emissions" numbers used in this Carbon Counter are expressed in carbon dioxide equivalents to account for different types of GHG emissions associated with the various activities (for example, diet -- which includes carbon dioxide and methane emissions -- or transportation -- which produces carbon dioxide emissions).

SolarPanel: solar panels operated for a year would offset your emissions.
Tree: A tree is most efficient at CO2 removal when it reaches ten years old. It would take
10-year-old trees one full year to remove your emissions.
Car: You produce the same emissions as driving an average car
SmartPhone: Your emissions are equal to the emissions produced from charging
SolidCarbon: Carbon dioxide is a gas that contains one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms. If all the carbon atoms in the GHGs from your emissions profile were put together in a solid chunk, it would be equivalent to a
pound bag of carbon (think of charcoal briquettes for grilling, which are made of 50-95% carbon) or coal.

intro.UNFCCC: Featuring exclusive content from the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

info: The following activity consists of videos taken of people attending the United Nations climate change negotiations held in Madrid, Spain in December 2019.
This annual event is known as the “COP,” which stands for the Conference of the Parties (“COP”) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (“UNFCCC”).

The UNFCCC is a formal international treaty established in 1992 to address climate change -- the United States became a party to the treaty when it was signed by President George H.W. Bush and then officially ratified (approved) by the U.S. Senate in 1992.
Many sub-agreements have been negotiated pursuant to the framework created by the UNFCCC, most famously the Paris Agreement in 2015.
The people in these videos are speaking spontaneously in response to the question we presented:  What do you want young people in the United States to know about climate change?

They had no time to prepare their comments and graciously and voluntarily agreed to be part of this project. The people on the videos are speaking for themselves, and do not necessarily represent the views or opinions of any country or organization. Some edits were made to the subtitles for clarity.
If you would like to participate and add a video, please contact
